body: What is the point of using `strtolower()` in this case?

IDs in the DOM are case sensitive, but they are not handled consistently across browsers. 
Having them all lowercase is an easy solution.
Alternatively we could also just use something like `base64_encode` which is available in PHP and JS...

> IDs in the DOM are case sensitive, but they are not handled consistently across browsers.

Does it matter? If we always use the same ID, case sensitivity should be irrelevant.

body:
@silberstreifen I've added some [test coverage](https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/pull/16841) for that method but I wasn't able to reproduce the test case you described. The attribute `bild_groÃŸ_dateiname` was not corrupted by the current method implementation with `strtolower()`. Could you please provide an attribute which actually breaks the tests?

Though I added a Cyrillic attribute which was not converted to lowercase previously.
@Kolyunya it actually was corrupted according to tests but in PHP 5.4 and PHP 5.5 only: https://travis-ci.org/yiisoft/yii2/builds/447569138?utm_source=github_status&utm_medium=notification
@samdark seems like there is some issue with the `mb_internal_encoding()`? Should we force the `UTF-8` while converting to lower case?
I was pretty sure that is going to help (tests pass now). My question was if should force encoding different from the system default.

I think it should be done same as in `encode()`:

```php
Yii::$app ? Yii::$app->charset : 'UTF-8'
```
Reworked the code to select the charset like the `encode()` method does.
